content.question: An object is spun in a horizontal circle such that it has a constant tangential speed at all points along its circular path of constant radius. A graph of the magnitude of the object’s tangential speed as a function of time is shown in the graph. Which of the following graphs could show the magnitude of the object’s centripetal acceleration as a function of time?

choices.label: The figure presents a graph. The horizontal axis is labeled Time, in seconds, and the numbers 0 through 10, in increments of 2, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Centripetal Acceleration, in meters per second squared, and the numbers 0 through 1.0, in increments of 0.2, are indicated. There is a curve on the graph that begins at 0 seconds, 0 meters per second, and moves to the right  on the horizontal axis, until 10 seconds, 0 meters per second squared.

The figure presents a graph. The horizontal axis is labeled “Time, in seconds,” and the numbers 0 through 10, in increments of 2, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Centripetal Acceleration, in meters per second squared,” and the numbers 0 through 10, in increments of 2, are indicated. There is a curve on the graph that begins at 0 seconds, 9 meters per second squared, and moves in a straight line, parallel to the horizontal axis, until 10 seconds, 9 meters per second squared.

The figure presents a graph. The horizontal axis is labeled Time, in seconds, and the numbers 0 through 10, in increments of 2, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Centripetal Acceleration, in meters per second squared, and the numbers 0 through 35, in increments of 5, are indicated. There is a curve on the graph that begins at 0 seconds, 0 meters per second squared, and moves steadily upward and to the right until 10 seconds, 30 meters per second squared.

The figure presents a graph. The horizontal axis is labeled Time, in seconds, and the numbers 0 through 10, in increments of 2, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Centripetal Acceleration, in meters per second squared, and the numbers negative 6 through 6, in increments of 2, are indicated. There is a curve on the graph that begins at 0 seconds, 0 meters per second squared, and moves upward and to the right until 2 seconds, 4 meters per second squared. The curve then moves downward and to the right until 6 seconds, negative 4 meters per second squared. The curve then moves upward and to the right until 10 seconds, 4 meters per second squared.
